results.title: The Beach = La Plage
results.creator_credit: Francine Desbiens, ONF | NFB and Suzanne Gervais
results.brief_description: This film touches upon the theme of solitude and is a fantasy that leaves the viewer free to speculate. A woman drowns, unnoticed by three men sitting with their backs to the sea. Two of them are throwing dice; the third is drinking a glass of water.

results.title: The Beach
results.creator_credit: Featherstone-Centrecoast Productions, Film Finance Corporation Australia, Don Featherstone and David Woodgate
results.brief_description: Along with the mystique of the bush and a fascination with the interior, the beach holds a resonance for many Australians, be it a place of relaxation, inhibition, spectacle, or the site of a rite of passage. This documentary looks at the icon of the beach, how it was introduced and has been represented through art, poetry, prose, film, music and choreography, as well as the history of beach culture - including cossies, codes of conduct and surfies. Key art works and literature are identified and reflected upon, with readings from “beach literature”, stills from paintings, photographs, film posters, plus footage of people at the beach. Includes interviews with numerous artists who talk about what the beach means to them and how it has influenced their work. Those interviewed include: Tim Winton, Juliana Engberg, Ken Done, Les Murray, Graham Murphy, Gabrielle Carey, Peter Sculthorpe, Doreen Mellor, George Ganyibala, Anne Zahalka and Philip Drew. Narrated by David Wenham.

results.title: The Beach
results.creator_credit: Andrew Macdonald, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Danny Boyle
results.brief_description: Based on Alex Garland’s best selling novel, this take on the Lord of the flies tale, reunites the production team (Danny Boyle, Andrew Macdonald, John Hodge) behind Shallow Grave and Trainspotting. Leonardo DiCaprio stars as Richard, a jaded American backpacker traveling around Thailand, in search of adventure. Bored with the familiar tourist routes the island has to offer, he happens upon Daffy (Robert Carlyle), a shady character who shows Richard a map to an island paradise that is hidden from the average tourist. Richard then takes the map and sets out along with a French couple (Virginie Ledoyen and Guillaume Canet) he meets in Bangkok in search of the mythical island. Once there however they discover that this secret utopia comes at a very dangerous price. Cast includes Tilda Swinton, Peter Gevisser, Lars Arentz-Hansen, Staffan Kihlbom. Special collectors edition includes: behind the scenes footage, alternate opening/ending, music video-All Saints “Pure Shore”, original theatrical trailer.

results.title: The Baymen
results.creator_credit: Peter Jones, ONF | NFB and Rex Tasker
results.brief_description: Baymen, no matter where they go, remain above all else Newfoundlanders. They were born to the sea, to a place in the life of their cliffside village, but many of the younger generation are now looking to the city for their future. This film shows the feelings of generation after generation of four families who have earned their living by gathering fish for over 400 years. How will the big industries now affect the lives of the Baymen? It follows a Bayman’s family to St. John’s (Vancouver Island), showing what such a change means to father, daughter and grandfather. Camera: Hector J. Lemieux.

results.title: The Bayeux Tapestry
results.creator_credit: Films du Compas, Roger Leenhardt and Jean-Pierre Vivet
results.brief_description: Follows closely the narrative sequences of the Bayeux Tapestry which is, more accurately, an embroidery - a piece of coarse linen 230 feet long and 20 inches wide. The story of Harold’s journey to the continent in 1064, his experiences in Europe, the battle of 1066 and finally his death. Its origin is uncertain but the consensus of expert opinion is that it is contemporary and was probably executed in England at the order of Bishop Odo of Bayeux, William the conquerors’ half-brother, as an ornament for his then new cathedral.

results.title: The Battleships
results.creator_credit: Rob McAuley, Film Finance Corporation Australia, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Peter Butt
results.brief_description: Prior to the nuclear bomb, the battleship was the most menacing machine known to man - a floating fortress of firepower in a time when ruling the oceans equated to ruling the world. This 4 part series looks at key sea battles of the 20th Century in the quest for global supremacy. Narrated by Robyn Williams, the series consists of archival footage, first person narratives and interviews with experts. “1800-1906: A Thirst for blood & iron”: Henry VIII instigates two centuries of a British maritime dynasty. Years later, iron clad warships provide the basis of America’s naval power. The United German Republic also features during this period with Japan joining them as a naval super power. “1906-1916: Clash of the Dreadnoughts”: In 1906 Britain upset the global balance of power by constructing the big gun battleship HMS Dreadnought - instigating an arms race that led to the largest confrontation in naval history. The greatest threat to Britain’s power came from Germany who had the second largest battle fleet in the world. Germany were quick to match Britain in the construction of new battleships, allies Austria and Italy were not far behind. Episode 2 covers the machinations of World War 1, U-boats, the British raid on Heligoland Bight and the Battle of Jutland. “1916-1939: The Darkness of the future”: The might of the battleship is questioned after in excess of 8000 British and German soldiers lose their lives in World War 1. Fingers are pointed in Britain, but Germany views the event as a tactical victory. The Washington Treaty attempts to put an end to the naval arms race, not everyone is agreeable however and Japan builds two of the biggest battleships ever seen, Yamato and Musachi, causing unease amongst the rest of the world. “1939-now: Terror from above”: The final episode in this epic series describes in detail the final years of World War II, including victories of the German U-boats and the trickle down effect on world trade. Coverage is provided of the Battle of Taranto and battleships Bismarck and Hood. Throughout the remainder of the war battleships were being replaced from the sky in the form of airplanes and the Aircraft Carrier, culminating in the attack on Pearl Harbour. The use of battleships post World War II continued to decline.

results.title: The Battlers
results.creator_credit: Gus Howard, South Australian Film Corporation and George Ogilvie
results.brief_description: Based on the novel of the same name by Kylie Tennant this made for television mini-series is set in Australia during the Great Depression. It focuses on the friendship between two ‘battlers’, Dancy, an orphan who has spent most of her life on the streets and Snow, a taciturn man on the rebound from a failed marriage. Forced to travel the country in search of work, like many working-class Australians of the time, and surviving mainly on dole book rations, their lives are full of hardship and deprivation, but the comradeship they develop on the road also brings them many moments of comfort and happiness. Cast includes Audine Lieth, Marcus Graham, Anne Phelan, Gary Sweet and Jacqueline McKenzie.

results.title: The Battle of Wangapore
results.brief_description: In this satirical animation British troops under a typical Colonel Blimp test the turbanned and rebellious riff-raff from over the border and all with a stiff sense of propriety. The story tracks back to the good old days on the North West Frontier of India. An example of animation technique as used by an amateur production group. Animation by Richard Horn and Ken Clark. (See also Title Code 006110 “Let battle begin” for the history of the making of the cartoon.)

results.title: The Battle of San Pietro
results.creator_credit: United States. Army Pictorial Service and John Huston
results.brief_description: Presents modern warfare from the soldier’s point of view. Stresses the number of men killed in taking one military objective. Shows how in the Allies Italian campaign, the people of San Pietro were too stunned to realise they had been liberated.

results.title: The Battle of Midway
results.creator_credit: John Ford and United States. Dept. of the Navy
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Why we fight”.
John Ford’s Academy Award winning documentary filmed during the Battle of Midway. Narration combines with visuals of the naval air battle, hospitalization of the injured and burial services in a patriotic tribute to the people from the United States battling the Japanese. Suitable for Tertiary level students.
